headline.main: SHUTTLE'S FIRE ALARM SOUNDS BUT CREW FINDS NO DANGER

results.snippet: A loud, warbling fire and smoke alarm sounded six times today aboard the space shuttle Challenger, sending the astronauts scrambling to find the cause, but they quickly reported everything was normal aboard the spacecraft 200 miles above the Earth....
results.lead_paragraph: A loud, warbling fire and smoke alarm sounded six times today aboard the space shuttle Challenger, sending the astronauts scrambling to find the cause, but they quickly reported everything was normal aboard the spacecraft 200 miles above the Earth. ''We did fire checks on both sides of the house and with no apparent anomalies,'' said the mission commander, Henry V. Hartsfield Jr. ''We're not sure what's going on.''

headline.main: REAGAN DROPS 11 IN FOREIGN POLICY ADVISORY GROUP

results.snippet: President Reagan has dismissed 11 of the 21 members of a committee of outside advisers who help him develop his foreign intelligence policies, the White House said today.   The White House disclosed nothing of its decision to ''streamline'' the...

byline.original: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan has dismissed 11 of the 21 members of a committee of outside advisers who help him develop his foreign intelligence policies, the White House said today. The White House disclosed nothing of its decision to ''streamline'' the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board until today, when the 11 members received the President's dismissal letter, dated Nov. 1. According to one of the recipients, Mr. Reagan said in his letter: ''It has become clear that the board has grown to a size which makes it difficult to focus intimately and actively on some of the new critical intelligence problems we will have to address. I intend therefore to reconstitute and streamline the board.''

headline.main: ASTONAUTS PACK UP EXPERIMENTS AS THEY PREPARE TO LAND TODAY

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger today put the finishing touches on their many scientific experiments and were set to conclude the weeklong mission with a landing Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base in California.   Officials at the West...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger today put the finishing touches on their many scientific experiments and were set to conclude the weeklong mission with a landing Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Officials at the West German Space Operations Center near Munich spoke of the mission's success in glowing terms, saying that the crew had accomplished nearly all the assigned research into the effects of weightlessness on metals processing, crystal growth, biological growth and human physiology. West Germany chartered the shuttle, paying the National Aeronautics and Space Administration a $65 million fee, and controlled the flight's scientific operations. Mission Control here directed the other operations.

headline.main: GERMANS CONTROL SPACE TESTS FROM HAMLET

results.snippet: For one week this unlikely Bavarian hamlet with a name as long as a countdown has been the control center for scientific experiments aboard the United States space shuttle Challenger.   In a sheet-metal shed, across a country road from apple trees...

byline.original: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: For one week this unlikely Bavarian hamlet with a name as long as a countdown has been the control center for scientific experiments aboard the United States space shuttle Challenger. In a sheet-metal shed, across a country road from apple trees and grazing cows, project controllers hover over glowing terminals. Nearby, Prof. Peter Sahm, the project's scientific director, explains to a casual news conference that a slime culture is growing more slowly than expected 200 miles aloft. In a converted airplane hangar, Col. Gordon Fullerton, a United States astronaut and the commander of a previous German-American mission, tells visiting schoolchildren what it is like to be weightless, and Marcus Buchwald, a 19-year-old high school student, shows the tiny wheat plants he grew from grain exposed to cosmic rays on that earlier German flight.

results.snippet: Question:I recently took my first global trip and would like to meet others who have had this experience. Do you know of any group or club exclusively for those who have traveled completely around the world? -B. T. P., New York Answer:The...
results.lead_paragraph: Question:I recently took my first global trip and would like to meet others who have had this experience. Do you know of any group or club exclusively for those who have traveled completely around the world? -B. T. P., New York Answer:The Circumnavigators Club, which was founded by two Americans in 1902, is an international organization devoted to bringing together travelers who have circled the globe. Helen Jost, executive secretary of its international headquarters in New York, says there are 10 chapters in other parts of the United States and 5 overseas. The total of more than 1,000 members includes those who belong to the international headquarters, which holds six to eight luncheon or dinner meetings a year. The guest of honor at the next meeting, a dinner at the Union League Club in New York on Thursday, will be the astronaut Sally Ride. She will be presented with the club's Order of Magellan, which is awarded to global travelers who have made a contribution to international understanding. Mrs. Jost said prospective members must submit evidence that they have traveled around the world and must be sponsored and seconded by members, who submit recommendations to the board. Must the trip have been made in one continuous journey? ''No, it can be done in parts, provided travelers pick up where they left off,'' Mrs. Jost said. ''But the circumnavigation must be in one direction.''

headline.main: DINNER AT THE WHITE HOUSE: LIST OF GUESTS

results.snippet: Following are the guests invited by President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, to the White House dinner Saturday night: The Prince and Princess of Wales. Sir Oliver Wright, British Ambassador to the United States, and Lady Wright. Sir John Riddell,...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Following are the guests invited by President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, to the White House dinner Saturday night: The Prince and Princess of Wales. Sir Oliver Wright, British Ambassador to the United States, and Lady Wright. Sir John Riddell, private secretary to the Prince. Michael Shea, press secretary to the Prince. David Roycroft, assistant private secretary to the Prince. Anne Beckwith-Smith, lady in waiting to the Princess. Lieut. Comdr. Peter Eberle, equerry to the Prince.

headline.main: ABC AND CBS GIVE UP ON THE MOVIE BUSINESS

results.snippet: Within a few weeks of each other, ABC and CBS have washed their hands of the movie business. CBS Theaterical Films and ABC Motion Pictures, founded with high hopes in 1979, have been closed and padlocked, and Hollywood is neither surprised nor...

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Within a few weeks of each other, ABC and CBS have washed their hands of the movie business. CBS Theaterical Films and ABC Motion Pictures, founded with high hopes in 1979, have been closed and padlocked, and Hollywood is neither surprised nor particularly disturbed. ''There were too many pictures in the marketplace last summer, 45, and, in that sense, losing some output is good,'' said Richard Zanuck, one of Hollywood's foremost independent producers. The latest CBS movie, ''Target,'' was produced by Zanuck-Brown. Starring Gene Hackman and directed by Arthur Penn, it opened last weekend to moderately good box-office response. Mr. Zanuck, who was in charge of production at 20th Century-Fox from 1962 to 1970, said, ''To stay in the movie business, you have to have a thick skin and you only get that by surviving many blows. This is a business of ups and downs and the major studios are mentally prepared for the hard knocks. The networks had their film divisions as appendages. So they were always in a secondary position.'' CBS announced its decision to abandon the movie business Wednesday; ABC closed its film operations Oct. 29.

results.snippet: THIS was in the coal fields of southwest Virginia more than a decade ago. My hosts had just finished serving a sumptuous Sunday dinner, and some of us were quite content to flop on the porch swing and enjoy the fall colors on the opposite ridge.  ...
results.lead_paragraph: THIS was in the coal fields of southwest Virginia more than a decade ago. My hosts had just finished serving a sumptuous Sunday dinner, and some of us were quite content to flop on the porch swing and enjoy the fall colors on the opposite ridge. The younger generation had another idea for the last hour before the sun dropped behind the mountain: a touch football game. They produced a ball and draped extra T-shirts to create sideline markers on the sloping front lawn, and then they recruited the sluggards on the front porch. I was a late-round draft choice.

results.snippet: International    The U.S. and Soviet leaders ended a two-day summit meeting in Geneva without achieving breakthroughs on key issues. But President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev approved a joint statement agreeing to step up arms negotiations and...
results.lead_paragraph: International The U.S. and Soviet leaders ended a two-day summit meeting in Geneva without achieving breakthroughs on key issues. But President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev approved a joint statement agreeing to step up arms negotiations and to meet more regularly. [Page A1, Columns 3-6.] President Reagan flew home and told Congress that his intensive talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva had opened the way for a ''new realism'' in American-Soviet relations and had created ''room for movement, action and progress.'' [A1:3-4.]

headline.main: BY NIGHT, ATLANTIS BEGINS 7-DAY MISSION    It was only the second time a shuttle has been launched at night. Tasks of the seven-member crew, which has the first Mexican astronaut to ride the shuttle, will include practicing building a space station. Page A18. (AP)
ASTRONAUTS LAUNCH A 3D SATELLITE AS THEY PREPARE FOR SPACE WALK

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis, celebrating ''one of the best'' Thanksgivings, launched an uninsured $50 million satellite today to clear the way for an important two-man space walk on Friday.   The Satcom satellite, owned by RCA American...
results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis, celebrating ''one of the best'' Thanksgivings, launched an uninsured $50 million satellite today to clear the way for an important two-man space walk on Friday. The Satcom satellite, owned by RCA American Communications Inc., was the last of three radio relay stations deployed from the space freighter's 60-foot cargo bay. ''Three for three,'' radioed Jim Wetherbee in mission control. ''Now we can look forward to some groundbreaking activities with your new construction techniques tomorrow.''

headline.main: AS HALLEY WAXES, WILL CITY WANE?

results.snippet: Mayor Koch has asked his science advisers for ''a reasonable plan'' to dim the city's lights to give New Yorkers a better chance to view Halley's comet.   The Mayor, however, cautioned officials of his Commission for Science and Technology that ''I...
results.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: Mayor Koch has asked his science advisers for ''a reasonable plan'' to dim the city's lights to give New Yorkers a better chance to view Halley's comet. The Mayor, however, cautioned officials of his Commission for Science and Technology that ''I cannot black out the city.'' But he said that, among other possibilities, decorative lighting on building facades and bridges and large outdoor advertising displays might be switched off or dimmed during certain periods sometime between Dec. 1 and Jan. 15, when the comet is expected to be most visible from the New York area. The dimming of lights would presumably be done voluntarily by private owners of buildings at the Mayor's request. A Major Preoccupation With comet-watching becoming a preoccupation, momentum had been building for plans to dim city lights.

headline.main: 2 PROVE NIMBLE BUILDERS FLOATING OUTSIDE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Leaving the security of the space shuttle Atlantis, two astronauts stepped into space today and spent much of the following five hours and 32 minutes practicing construction techniques that will be needed in building orbiting stations of the...

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Leaving the security of the space shuttle Atlantis, two astronauts stepped into space today and spent much of the following five hours and 32 minutes practicing construction techniques that will be needed in building orbiting stations of the future. As Maj. Jerry L. Ross and Lieut. Col. Sherwood C. Spring floated weightless from one task to another, they worked so efficiently and quickly that there was ample time for banter and for admiring the view of the Earth as it wheeled overhead. The trouble-free space construction exercise capped a mission that has been flawless since the Atlantis lifted off its pad at the Kennedy Space Center Tuesday night. Instruments monitoring the astronauts' heartbeats and rates of oxygen consumption indicated two hours into the exercise that the heavy exertion was tiring them somewhat, but they continued to complete their assignments ahead of schedule.

headline.main: Lizard in Computer Disrupts Shuttle Post

results.snippet: An 18-inch lizard disrupted operation of a computer briefly Thursday at an African ground station tracking the space shuttle Atlantis, Mission Control reported today.   Sally Ride, an astronaut in the Houston control center, told the shuttle crew...
results.lead_paragraph: An 18-inch lizard disrupted operation of a computer briefly Thursday at an African ground station tracking the space shuttle Atlantis, Mission Control reported today. Sally Ride, an astronaut in the Houston control center, told the shuttle crew that the tracking station in Dakar, Senegal, had experienced a momentary power fluctuation that halted the computer.
